aboutTarot.title: About Tarot
aboutTarot.description: A journey through the ages of mystical wisdom and self-discovery

1.title: Birth of Tarot
1.description: The first mentions of Tarot cards appear in Renaissance Italy. Initially, they were used as ordinary playing cards among the aristocracy. The oldest surviving decks are the Visconti-Sforza Tarot, created for Milanese nobility.

2.title: Spread Across Europe
2.description: Tarot spreads throughout Europe, especially in France and Switzerland. The first standardized decks appear, including the Marseille Tarot. Cards are mainly used for games, but occult interpretations begin to emerge.

3.title: Mystical Reinterpretation
3.description: French occultists, notably Antoine Court de Gébelin, began attributing ancient Egyptian origins and esoteric meanings to Tarot cards. This laid the foundation for the modern tradition of Tarot divination.

4.title: Golden Age of Occultism
4.description: Tarot becomes an integral part of Western esotericism. Éliphas Lévi connects the cards with Kabbalah and the Hebrew alphabet. New esoteric decks are created. The Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn is founded, developing a complex system of Tarot correspondences.

5.title: Rider-Waite Tarot
5.description: In 1909, the Rider-Waite deck is published, created by Arthur Edward Waite and artist Pamela Colman Smith. It becomes the most influential deck of the 20th century thanks to detailed illustrations on all cards, including the Minor Arcana.

6.title: Psychological Approach
6.description: Carl Jung and his followers interpret Tarot through the lens of depth psychology and archetypes. Tarot begins to be seen as a tool for self-knowledge and psychological work, not just divination.

7.title: Creative Flourishing
7.description: Thousands of custom decks appear for every taste: from traditional to avant-garde, from fantasy to minimalist. Tarot becomes mainstream, used for meditation, creativity, coaching, and personal development.

philosophyTarot.title: Philosophy of Tarot
philosophyTarot.description1: Tarot is not just a tool for divination, but a system of symbols that helps us understand the deep patterns of our life and subconscious.
philosophyTarot.description2: Each card contains multilayered symbolism combining astrological, numerological, kabbalistic, and archetypal meanings. Working with Tarot is a dialogue with one's own soul.
philosophyTarot.description3: Modern practices use Tarot for meditation, self-analysis, creative inspiration, and psychological development. It is a tool that helps us ask the right questions and find answers within ourselves.
philosophyTarot.descriptionAccent: Tarot does not predict the future - it helps us create it
